In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Support by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for economic and strategic management 
in Tonga began in 2002 with the Economic and Public Sector Reform Program (EPSRP),1 which 
aimed to help the government address slow economic growth; inequality in income distribution 
and  access  to  services;  and  unemployment  and  poverty.  This  was  followed  by  technical 
assistance (TA) to support the formulation of the Strategic Development Plan 2006/07–2008/09 
(SDP-8),2 and TA for Support for the Implementation of SDP-8.3 During a country contact 
mission in March 2009, the government requested ADB assistance towards the implementation 
of the successor planning document to SDP-8, which ended in June 2009. The government also 
confirmed that there is limited economic and policy analysis to support decision-making and the 
annual budget process. Specific areas identified for support include macroeconomic analysis 
and forecasting and budget analysis. The key central agencies such as the Ministry of Finance 
and National Planning (MFNP), Public Service Commission (PSC), and the Prime Minister's 
Office (PMO) also need to strengthen their provision of technical and policy advice, as the 
overall success of policymaking and public financial management depends on each agency 
fulfilling its role. In addition, there is a pressing need to see the central agencies work together 
more effectively. This requires a closely coordinated and coherent approach to strengthening 
economic  and  public  financial  management.  The  capacity  development  TA  will  be 
complemented by a regional TA supporting economic management in the Pacific in response to 
the global economic crisis.4  
 
2.  An ADB fact-finding mission was conducted in June 2009 to reach an understanding 
with  the  government  on  the  objectives  and  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and the detailed terms of reference for consulting services of the 
capacity development TA. The proposed capacity development TA has been included in the TA 
program for 2009 in ADB’s country operations business plan 2010–20125 and is consistent with 
the strategic objectives of Responding to the Priorities of the Poor: A Pacific Strategy for the 
Asian Development Bank 2005–2009.6 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB's country partnership strategy 2007–20128 for Tonga supported the implementation 
of the SDP-8. ADB’s country partnership strategy has three intervention pillars to address 
Tonga's  growth  constraints:  (i)  integrated  urban  infrastructure  development,  (ii)  prudent 
macroeconomic and fiscal management, and (iii) private sector development. The follow-on TA 
for Support for the Implementation of SDP-8 primarily addressed goal 2 of the SDP-8 to ensure 
macroeconomic stability through strengthening capacity in the areas of development planning,

expenditure process. 
  
4.  The  SDP-8  ended  in  June  2009  and  Cabinet  endorsed  the  new  national  strategic 
planning framework (NSPF). The NSPF: (i) takes a longer-term strategic approach to achieving 
sustainable  development  (5–10  years),  with  attention  focused  on  the  key  determinants  of 
economic and social development; and (ii) focuses on a limited number of uniquely national or 
government-wide priorities, with implementation details to be contained in the corporate plans of 
ministries and departments. The NSPF identified seven outcomes regarded as fundamental to 
producing sustained and more equitable economic growth in Tonga. These are (i) community 
development that meets service needs; (ii) private sector growth (through better engagement 
with the government, appropriate incentives and streamlining of rules and regulations); (iii) 
constitutional reform; (iv) improved provision and maintenance of infrastructure; (v) increased 
performance  of  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training  to  meet  the  challenges of 
maintaining and developing services and infrastructure; (vi) improved health of the people by 
minimizing the impact of non-communicable diseases; and (vii) environmental sustainability and 
climate change integrated into all program planning and execution. The three pillars of ADB's 
strategy for Tonga remain valid in light of the outcome objectives highlighted under the NSPF. 
 
5.  The NSPF is being refined to include performance targets and indicators and will be 
operationalized by ministry and department corporate plans, which are intended to link to the 
budget process; these will align the NSPF with national priorities, and ministry and department 
objectives and resource allocations. The NSPF also requires a more robust management and 
monitoring  mechanism  to  track  the  achievement  of  strategic  objectives,  which  challenges 
ministries and departments to focus on the quality of their corporate plans. The Expenditure 
Review Committee (ERC), chaired by the Prime Minister, provides more strategic direction to 
the government's budget, financial management, and economic policymaking. The capacity of 
ministries for planning varies, however, and support is consequently needed to strengthen the 
capacity of line ministries to support economic management. Activities to finalize the NSPF and 
prepare  corporate  plans  are  now  underway  with  support  from  the  Australian  Agency  for 
International Development. The proposed capacity development TA will continue this work, and 
will, in particular, strengthen the link to the overall budget process, as well as the updated 
medium-term budget framework (MTBF). 
 
6.  ADB’s TA for Support for the Implementation of SDP-8 was designed to support the 
implementation of SDP-8, but suffered from a number of problems. The TA helped prepare an 
MTBF and provided useful guidance for improvements in public financial management. The 
MTBF lacked strategic direction; however, due to the absence of a clear overarching strategy at 
the time it was prepared, particularly in terms of medium-term resource allocation. Further work 
is  therefore  required  in  light  of  the  new  NSPF.  The  MTBF  has  helped  MFNP  prioritize 
investment projects for possible development partner financing, but further support is required to 
revise the MTBF and enable it to serve as a useful resource allocation tool. While the focus is 
on the MTBF, it is also important to note that the Budget Division of MFNP has experienced 
significant recent staff turnover, and much expertise in budgeting has consequently been lost. 
The  Budget  Division  therefore  requires  capacity  development  in  budget  preparation  and 
analysis, which should include turning the MTBF into a more strategic tool. The CDTA will 
support the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre (PFTAC) who will lead the MTBF 
activities with the Government. 
 
7.  The Economic, Social, Policy and Planning Division of MFNP (known as Policy and 
Planning) has a diverse role, including provision of economic reports (quarterly and monthly);

3
economic, debt and sector policy analysis; revenue and GDP forecasting; planning and plan 
monitoring, reviewing, and reporting; and development of procurement policy among others. 
Strategic planning has been identified as a weak area, partly as one of two positions dedicated 
to this function remains unfilled. The adoption of a much more succinct strategic planning 
framework will place the onus on the ministries and departments to ensure corporate plans (i) 
are aligned with the NSPF, (ii) contain valid and measurable targets and indicators, and (iii) are 
used  as  management  and  performance  assessment  tools.  While  responsibility  for  the 
preparation of corporate plans rests squarely with the ministries and departments concerned, 
Policy and Planning has an important role in helping ensure that the plans are fully aligned with 
the  NSPF,  and  that  the  targets  and  indicators  contained  in  them  can  be  measured  and 
aggregated, to assist in monitoring and reporting on national strategic plan achievement. The 
PSC has a key coordinating role in the preparation of corporate plans, which it will use as the 
basis for its performance management system, which is expected to be implemented during 
2009–2010. Policy and Planning and the PSC will need to work closely together in helping 
ministries and departments prepare their corporate plans.  
 
8.  Policy and Planning also needs an improved model to assist in GDP and revenue 
forecasting—a common model should be used by the National Reserve Bank of Tonga (NRBT), 
Statistics Department and the PMO. A model developed in Samoa with ADB assistance is being 
evaluated with a view to customizing it for use in Tonga. Some assistance is also required in the 
areas  of  more  timely  and  relevant  policy  analysis.  It  is  proposed  that  ADB’s  capacity 
development  TA  provide  assistance  to  address  the  above  identified  needs  in  Policy  and 
Planning. 
 
9.  The PMO supports the ERC and is playing an increasing role in policy coordination and 
overall policy direction setting. The greater involvement of the PMO and ERC provides the basis 
for (i) more strategic management of the budget process; and (ii) clearer strategic guidance to 
ministries and departments on policy priorities, making policy choices, and arbitrating between 
departments. As NSPF implementation proceeds, the ERC will need to be informed on progress 
relative  to  performance  targets  in  order  to  (i)  inform  its  decision  making  to  improve 
implementation; and (ii) where required, establish new priorities and targets. The Australian 
Agency for International Development is supporting the work of the ERC through structural 
reviews of ministries. ADB recently provided funding for the services of an economic and 
strategy adviser to the Prime Minister, and it is proposed that this support be continued under 
the capacity development TA.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The intended impact of the capacity development TA is enhanced resource allocation to 
foster  economic  growth  and  achieve  national  development  priorities.  The  impact  will  be 
monitored through demonstrated improvements in the country performance assessment ratings 
in macroeconomic management and the quality of budgetary and financial management. The 
expected TA outcome will be the adoption by the Government of Tonga of improved economic 
and strategic management processes. The achievement of this outcome will be reflected in 
improvements in public expenditure and financial accountability ratings.

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The following outputs are envisaged: (i) regular monitoring and reporting on progress of 
the NSPF, (ii) use of a GDP and revenue forecasting model, (iii) presentation to decision 
makers of robust and timely economic policy analysis and proposals, (iv) an MTBF that is 
strategically aligned and used, and (v) improved policy coordination. 
 
12.  Key activities for output 1 include (i) establishing a monitoring and reporting process for 
the NSPF, and (ii) capacity development in the monitoring of corporate plan progress and the 
alignment of corporate plans with resource allocations. For output 2, key activities will include (i) 
evaluating and customizing a GDP and revenue-forecasting model; (ii) establishing the model in 
the  Policy  and  Planning  Division,  the  NRBT,  and  Statistics  Department;  (iii)  developing 
supporting manuals; and (iv) conducting relevant training and capacity building. For output 3, 
activities will include (i) research on topical issues, in particular domestic and global trends and 
developments that are likely to impact on the Tongan economy; and (ii) preparation of relevant 
and timely policy papers to advise on the formulation of appropriate policy responses to mitigate 
the impacts of domestic and external shocks. For output 4, the activities include (i) developing a 
strategically aligned MTBF, and (ii) establishing a process for updating and using the MTBF. For 
output 5, the activities include (i) providing advice to the Prime Minister, (ii) providing support to 
ERC, and (iii) liaising between the ERC and ministries and departments. 
 
13.  As part of its constitutional reforms, Tonga expects to hold its first democratic elections 
at the end of 2010. A potential risk is that a new government, with limited parliamentary and 
ministerial experience, may emphasize different development priorities, raising uncertainties 
with respect to project implementation. One mitigating factor is the strengthening of the role of 
the chief executive officers and senior management officials in providing relevant advice to 
incoming  political  leaders,  and  having  the  capacity  to  ensure  implementation  continuity. 
Corporate planning activities undertaken to implement the NSPF will strengthen the capacity of 
chief executive officers, and will be complemented by ongoing public service reforms. ADB 
should continue to engage a wide range of key stakeholders in programming discussions and 
project and TA processing to ensure that a minimum level of awareness is maintained, and 
allow for continued support during post-election implementation. 
 
14.  There is a need for continuing coordination—through regular dialogue and information 
sharing—with other key development partners regarding economic and public sector reforms 
(Supplementary Appendix A), and with ADB's regional TA for Pacific Economic Management 
(footnote 4). ADB recently established a joint country focal office with the World Bank Group in 
Tonga,  and  a  Tongan  national  has  been  selected  as  the  country  focal  officer.  This  will 
strengthen collaboration between ADB and the World Bank, and also provide an on-the-ground 
presence  for  both  institutions  for  ease  of  coordination  with  the  government  and  other 
development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the capacity development TA is estimated at the equivalent of $625,000, 
of which $500,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, 
funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the equivalent of $125,000 
in-kind  through  the  provision  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  and  local 
communication. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MFNP will be the executing agency for the capacity development TA and will ensure that 
TA activities are closely coordinated with the implementing agencies—e.g., the Budget and 
Policy  and  Planning  divisions,  PMO  (for  forecasting  and  policy  coordination),  NRBT  (for 
economic analysis, management and forecasting), Statistics Department (for forecasting), and 
line ministries (for corporate planning)—as well as other key stakeholders. The ERC will be the 
steering committee for the capacity development TA, while the recently revived Macroeconomic 
Technical Committee will oversee the implementation of support from various development 
partners,  and  monitor  progress  by  the  implementing  agencies.  The  Macroeconomic 
Coordinating  Committee  will  be  chaired  by  the  secretary  for  finance  and  includes 
representatives  from  the  key  central  agencies  such  as  the  PMO,  NRBT,  and  Statistics 
Department. The Macroeconomic Technical Committee will also act as the conduit between the 
ERC (which provides policy direction), the Project and Aid Coordinating Committee (which 
conducts investment project appraisals), and line ministries. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 2 years, from January 2010 to December 
2011.  ADB  will  engage  international,  regional,  and  national  consultants  with  expertise  in 
planning, economic policy, economic modeling and budget analysis through a firm using the 
quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method,  after  seeking  simplified  technical  proposals.  An 
individual consultant will be selected in addition to a firm.9 The consultants will be engaged 
according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
The TA will require about 35 person-months of consulting services comprising about 15 person-
months of international, 8 person-months of international or regional, and 12 person-months of 
regional or national consultant services to carry out the activities as defined in the terms of 
reference (Appendix 3). The experts will be supplemented by ADB's regional TA resources, 
including the ADB–World Bank Group country focal officer and experts under ADB’s TA for 
Pacific Economic Management, as required. The proceeds of the capacity development TA will 
be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.10 
 
18.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the capacity development TA, and a final report summarizing the 
achievements, issues, lessons learned, and next steps. Throughout the capacity development 
TA, the team leader will submit (by e-mail) brief monthly progress reports summarizing TA 
activities, progress, issues, and constraints. Team members will produce inputs (reports) on 
their respective activities for the team leader's progress and final reports. The team leader's final 
report will be submitted in draft form at least 5 weeks prior to the end of the assignment, and the 
final report within 2 weeks of receipt of comments by the government and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Tonga for Support for Economic and Strategic Management, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of a team of international, regional, 
and national consultants in planning, economic policy formulation, and economic modeling.  
 
B.  Specific 
 
1.  Planning  and  Economic  Policy  Specialist  –  Team  Leader  (international  or 
regional, 8 person-months) 
2.  The specialist will be a macroeconomist with a strong background in development planning 
as well as broad experience in the Pacific and other regions. 
 
3.  In addition to overall coordination of all TA activities, the specialist will:  
 
(i)  in close consultation with the Ministry of Finance and National Planning (MFNP), the 
Prime Minister’s Office, the National Reserve Bank of Tonga, and the Statistics 
Department, prepare a time-bound detailed TA implementation work plan, including 
a training program with clear milestones; 
(ii)  support MFNP and relevant line ministries to prepare and implement seminars and 
workshops, including stakeholder workshops; 
(iii)  support MFNP and line ministries in key economic sectors to improve budget output 
definitions and performance indicators in support of the national planning framework, 
sector and corporate plans, by 
(a)  assisting  and  strengthening  the  capacity  of  MFNP  and  relevant  line 
ministries  in  monitoring  (1)  progress  in  achieving  specific  performance 
indicators, and (2) overall macro- and sector-level economic performance. 
This will include monitoring of strategic plan progress; and 
(b)  reviewing  the  strategic  alignment  of  the  medium-term  budget  framework 
(MTBF) with the new strategic plan, and developing a process for MTBF 
updates; 
(iv)  support and strengthen the capacity of staff in MFNP and relevant line ministries in 
the analysis of outputs from national accounts and economic models; 
(v)  assist  in  designing  and  conducting  relevant  training  in  strategic  development 
planning and macroeconomics and policy analysis, including a training of trainers 
program;  
(vi)  coordinate  closely  with  the  PFTAC  Public  Financial  Management  Advisor  with 
regards to the MTBF activities; and 
(vii)  provide  regular  progress  reports  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  the 
Government of Tonga in accordance with the TA implementation work plan. 
 
2.  Economic Modeling Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will: 
 
(i)  evaluate and customize gross domestic product and forecasting models; 
(ii)  establish new models in key agencies like MFNP, the National Reserve Bank of 
Tonga, and the Statistics Department; 
(iii)  develop support manuals for the models; and

3.  Economic and Strategy Adviser (international, 12 person-months)

(i)  support the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC) through the submission of timely 
papers  and  analysis—on  a  proactive  basis,  where  possible—on  statistical  and

(ii)  assist  MFNP  and  other  ministries  in  formulating  and  monitoring  realistic

(iii)  assist the government to establish a monitoring and reporting process in association 
with implementation of the new strategic plan; and 
(iv)  facilitate effective collaboration between the ERC and ministries and departments in

4.  Budget Adviser (regional or national, 12 person-months) 
 
6.  The adviser will: 
 
(i)  will coordinate closely with the PFTAC Public Financial Management Advisor; 
(ii)  assist with the development of a strategically aligned MTBF, and a process to 
update the MTBF based on the outcome of the PFTAC scoping work; 
(iii)  assist the Budget Division in budget preparation; 
(iv)  assist  with  the  alignment  of  budget  provisions  with  the  medium-term  budget 
provisions set out in the government’s MTBF; 
(v)  assist in aligning the budget provisions with the goals and strategies of the new 
national strategic planning framework and corporate plans of line ministries; 
(vi)  assist in incorporating policy directives and other ERC initiatives in the budget;

(viii)  provide capacity building for staff of the Budget Division on budgeting principles, 
best practice, common problems, and the incorporation of strategic objectives in

 COORDINATED SUPPORT TO ECONOMIC AND STRATEGIC MANAGEMENT 
 
1.  Public sector finances have improved significantly in the past two years. Earlier in the 
decade,  substantial  progress  had  been  made  in  reducing  endemic  public  sector  deficits—by 
FY2004, government accounts were in surplus and remained so for FY2005. However, the civil 
service strike in 2005 and the consequent large increase in public sector wages and salaries had a 
substantial negative impact on the fiscal position. Even though there was a large subsequent 
downsizing  of  the  civil  service,  the  pay  increases  and  the  redundancy  packages  increased 
government expenditure by the equivalent of 15% of GDP in the two years ending June 2007. 
However,  the  Government  managed  the  impact  prudently.  Helped  by  a  strong  revenue 
performance and significant expenditure cuts, deficits were limited to 1.8% of GDP in FY2006 and 
the budget balance was in surplus in FY2007. The Government further tightened its fiscal stance in 
FY2008 and achieved a more substantial surplus of 2.2% of GDP. The Government needs to build 
on its fiscal prudence by improving its economic and strategic management. 
 
2.  The Economic and Public Sector Reform Program (EPRSP) put in place the institutional 
and legislative framework for public financial management, public enterprise management, and 
public service delivery. However, the program was not fully implemented. Generally, preparation of 
regulations supporting the newly adopted legislation was slow and enforcement remained weak 
due to resource constraints and lack of political commitment. Importantly, the issue of downsizing 
the public service was not addressed and nor was an effective performance management system 
linked to better public service delivery put in place. Macroeconomic performance in 2002–2005 fell 
short of EPRSP targets. Subsequently, a voluntary redundancy program, initiated in the first half of 
2006, downsized the public service, but there was no strategic dimension to this (i.e., prioritization 
of where the cuts should be made).   
 
3.  The  ADB  TA  to  support  the  implementation  of  SDP-8  provided  useful  guidance  for 
improvements in public financial management which largely confirmed and built on an earlier public 
expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment. Together, these assessments clearly 
identify the areas for improving public financial management. Progress of this will be monitored 
through future PEFA assessments and AusAID has indicated its interest in supporting improved 
public financial management. ADB is well placed to provide technical backstopping through its 
Country Focal Officer in Tonga and staff in its Suva office as required. AusAID TA support would 
be centered on the Treasury Division of MFNP. 
 
4.  Economic policy making in Tonga suffers from weaknesses in the availability and reliability 
of economic data. A recent IMF Article IV mission concluded that improved economic statistics 
(particularly in the areas of national accounts and balance of payments) will enhance policy making. 
Recent work by the Statistics Adviser of the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre (PFTAC) 
has provided recommendations for what needs to be done to remedy this situation. The Statistics 
Department needs improved leadership and technical strengthening. AusAID has indicated its 
willingness to provide assistance to the Statistics Department. It is expected that PFTAC will 
provide technical backstopping as required. 
 
5.  The NRBT suffers from a severe and persistent lack of technical skills in the areas of 
economic analysis, monetary policy formulation and banking supervision, particularly of non bank 
financial institutions. NRBT has been developing its system for data collection and dissemination 
and undertaking basic analysis of such data over the past few years. There is now a need to 
leverage current dataset and improve analytical ability to be of greater benefit for monetary policy 
formulation, improved economic management and banking supervision. Support is needed through 
a relevant technical expert to work within the Research Department to improve economic analysis,

12  Supplementary Appendix A 
 
management  and  forecasting.  Banking  supervision  and  monetary  policy  would  be  most 
appropriately supported by PFTAC with or without longer term support from another development 
partner. 
 
6.  With support from the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), the Public 
Service Commission has started a structural review of departments with work ongoing for three 
departments (Ministry of Finance and Planning, Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries, Forestry and 
Food, and Revenue Services Department). The results will be considered by the Expenditure 
Review Committee (ERC). The decisions made from this exercise will also be reflected in the new 
corporate plans. In turn, a revised medium term budget framework (MTBF) will flow out of the new 
strategically aligned ministry and department corporate plans. The corporate plans will provide the 
basis for PSC to manage the performance of the public sector senior managers.
